title: Poor Dan is in a Droop
subtitle: Digital Comic | May 2023
overview: Poor Dan is in a Droop is a semester-long collaborative project exploring complex concepts in quantum physics through interactive storytelling. Our team of five—including three artists and two developers—created a digital comic that visualizes the bi-directional flow of time via Dan’s life story and mental-health journey. The project challenged us to convey abstract ideas clearly while integrating interactivity, mini-games, and visually compelling animations. For me, this was an early exploration in game development, where I applied object-oriented programming principles to manage game systems and mechanics effectively.
contributions: Led development and organized project workflow for a team of five.
Designed and implemented interactive mini-games using Unity and C#, applying object-oriented programming principles to structure game mechanics efficiently.
Coordinated with artists to integrate visuals and narrative elements seamlessly into the interactive comic.
challenges: Learned to balance narrative clarity with technical constraints, honing project scope management skills.
Explored object-oriented programming in a hands-on context, gaining foundational experience in structuring game logic, managing game objects, and handling interactive systems.
Navigated the complexities of combining storytelling with interactive gameplay, strengthening problem-solving and collaboration abilities.
mediaCaption: Demo Video of Poor Dan is in a Droop

title: Geoscience Exhibit
subtitle: 3D Exhibit for Android | February 2024
overview: Developed a Unity-based Android application for the 2024 Personal Structures Exhibition in Venice, Italy. The exhibit presents 3D geological drone data from Boise State University's Human-Environment Systems department, allowing users to explore the environment and learn about invasive plant species in Idaho. Features include immersive navigation, gyroscopic camera controls, and a seasonal slider showing environmental changes throughout the year.
contributions: Assisted with implementing core C# functionality
Designed UX interactions for navigation and environmental sliders
Optimized the game loop for quick playthroughs for exhibitors
challenges: Converting raw drone point cloud data into an optimized 3D model using Blender
Developing shaders for smooth seasonal transitions
Balancing performance and usability for a public exhibit environment
mediaCaption: In-experience view of the Geoscience Exhibit

title: ABC Stories
subtitle: AR Educational | May 2024
overview: ABCStories is an iPad app that helps children learn the alphabet through interactive AR stories they can place in the real world. I collaborated with a team to completely overhaul the app, replacing a costly web-based backend with a standalone data management system. This redesign eliminated reliance on third-party hosting, saving our client approximately $1,000 per month while maintaining FERPA compliance.
contributions: Co-developed core data collection functionality in Swift
Designed the standalone data management system, transitioning from a web-hosted backend
Collaborated on UX design to optimize local account navigation
challenges: Navigated my first Swift project, rapidly building proficiency in iOS development and ARKit.
Learned how to design and implement a secure, local data solution while maintaining educational functionality.

title: Fish & Game: Hunter Safety VR
subtitle: VR Simulation | May 2025
overview: A VR classroom training tool developed with 13 state Fish & Wildlife departments on a six-figure budget. The application supplements hunter safety courses by letting students safely practice firearm handling and ethical decision-making in immersive scenarios.
contributions: Led scenario design for classroom VR simulations
Co-designed a proprietary firearm handling system for safe, intuitive training
Provided post-delivery support to partner states and instructors
challenges: Team scaling: Coordinated with a team of 18, establishing new workflows for scalable solution development and cross-discipline communications
Timeline pressure: Delivered within the original scope despite a 5-month delayed start
User accessibility: Designed interactions simple enough for learners of a wide age range in time-limited classroom settings
mediaCaption: Gameplay trailer for Fish & Game: Hunter Safety VR

title: FirelineFlyers
subtitle: 3D Networked Multiplayer | est. May 2026
overview: FirelineFlyers is an ongoing indie project exploring Unreal Engine and real-time multiplayer networking. Designed as a co-op arcade experience, players team up to pilot planes and extinguish fires under time pressure. The project serves both as a technical challenge in networking and as a creative experiment in fast-paced cooperative gameplay.
contributions: Implemented the networking framework for synchronized cooperative play
Prototyped the core gameplay loop including flight controls, firefighting mechanics, and scoring
Developed Unreal Engine workflows while transitioning from Unity
Iterating on game balance and fire behavior systems as part of ongoing development
challenges: Adapting to Unreal Engine after years of Unity development
Designing and testing real-time multiplayer networking from scratch
Balancing arcade gameplay scope with expanding technical systems
Maintaining project direction as features evolve during prototyping

title: BSU's Kestrel Conservation Experience
subtitle: VR Simulation | September 2025
overview: Kestrel is a VR educational simulation developed over the course of 2 months in collaboration with the BSU Raptor Research Center and Meta. The project explores new ways to teach environmental science through fully immersive, hand-tracked interactions.
contributions: Oversaw the development cycle and iterated on workflows and procedures
Built modular Unity systems with low-level control via Unity Events and the Inspector
Created software utilities to streamline development for both programmers and designers
challenges: Developing a hand-tracking only application — a first for our team
Designing tools that were both generic and accessible to unfamiliar developers
Improving documentation practices so collaborators could adopt systems quickly

title: VARScent
subtitle: VR Health Research | est. May 2026
overview: VARScent is a VR project developed with Boise State Psychology and Engineering departments. The experience pairs immersive VR environments with scent delivery to assist researchers in gathering data related to early signs of dementia. The project aims to create quick, repeatable, and intuitive tests that can be used in controlled research environments.
contributions: Redesigning and modernizing an existing prototype to improve stability and maintainability
Implementing a single source of truth for research data to reduce duplication and errors
Streamlining communication between Unity and Arduino hardware for reliable scent delivery
Enhancing UX design to ensure tests are intuitive, repeatable, and accessible to participants
challenges: Integrating VR hardware with scent-based devices in a consistent and controlled way
Redesigning legacy codebases while ensuring continuity for ongoing research
Balancing research requirements with usability and technical constraints
contributors: Sam Lummus, Kate Hillyard, Austin Yarnot, Kaden Vissotski

title: Harmony of The Spheres
subtitle: 2D Indie Puzzle | est. December 2025
overview: Harmony of The Spheres is an ongoing indie local-multiplayer puzzle game designed to be fully accessible for individuals with complete colorblindness. The project combines procedural puzzle generation with a custom Arduino-powered controller to create an immersive and inclusive gameplay experience.
contributions: Led solution design with a focus on conveying gameplay information without color cues
Developed algorithms for procedural puzzle generation to increase replayability
Designed and prototyped a custom Arduino controller for enhanced immersion
Collaborated on accessibility testing and gameplay iteration
challenges: Accessibility: Designing a puzzle system without using color as a mechanic required reliance on shapes, sounds, text, and haptics
Hardware: Developing a unique Arduino controller and ensuring seamless Unity integration for player input
Iteration: Balancing accessibility needs with engaging gameplay mechanics during prototyping

title: Skeet Shooter VR
subtitle: VR Sport Simulation | est. December 2025
overview: Skeet Shooter VR is a special topics project created for GIMM 480, developed in collaboration with Sam Lummus. The project focuses on delivering a highly realistic skeet shooting simulation that provides users with a safe and accessible way to practice the sport. Our long-term goal is to publish the game on Steam, pushing the boundaries of feasible realism in VR sports experiences.
contributions: Co-developed the VR simulation framework alongside Sam Lummus
Designed and implemented gameplay systems that replicate skeet shooting mechanics
Experimented with interaction models to enhance immersion and realistic firearm handling
Collaborated on Steam release preparation and publishing pipeline research
challenges: Achieving convincing realism within the limits of available VR hardware
Balancing playability and authenticity to ensure both casual and serious players can engage
Researching and applying best practices for VR firearm handling
Preparing for the technical and logistical challenges of publishing on Steam
